characters: MUSIC UP. BEGIN A SERIES OF SHOTS
BUD LITE AND THE BLACK TACKLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allright, bowl bid ridin' here for  E.S.U. Fourth down on the Georgia  Tech 18. 4 ticks left. Kane sets 'em  down.

dialogues.speaker: LINE OF TAPED KNUCKLES
dialogues.text: smashing into the mud, as a football OFFENSIVE LINE comes set, frosted breath steaming across to: The DEFENSIVE LINE digging in, ready to explode.

dialogues.speaker: JOE KANE
dialogues.text: E.S.U. quarterback, barking signals. The ball is snapped, and we go to SLOW MOTION as the lines crash together in t slop. Joe rolls to the right, looking downfield. A huge DEFENSI END bears down on him. Joe jukes. The end whips on by,  grabbing for jersey, slipping off. But big NUMBER 75 is  closing the gap. On the run, Joe releases a desperation p toward the end zone, just as 75 catches him and buries hi face-down in the swamp. We FOLLOW THE BALL, spiraling through the slanting rain. GRIFFEN, black running back, glances back for it, two  DEFENSIVE BACKS with him. All three leap in unison, climb as high as they can, clutching, clawing for the ball. The ball floats down, kisses off the tangle of fingers, splas to the ground, and rolls to a stop in the mud. Incomplete The BANG of the final gun snaps us back to LIVE ACTION. Joe on his knees in the muck, stares at the goal line, th drops his head in defeat.

dialogues.speaker: SAM WINTERS
dialogues.text: Betraying little emotion, Coach SAM WINTERS, wiry, intens early 50's, takes off his headset, lets it drop, heads ac the field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coach, this is the second year in a  row you've failed to go to a bowl  game. Do you feel your program's in  decline?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coach Winters stands outside his office surrounded by  reporters, a bouquet of microphones stuck in his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (keeping his cool) No, we're just a young team on the  verge. We'll be back in a major bowl  next year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elsewhere in the locker room, we pick up a weary, mud- splattered Joe Kane taking off his pads in front of his  locker. ALVIN MACK, black linebacker, comes by. Alvin exu danger; big, fast and hostile on the field, slightly surl a sense of repressed anger off it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good throw, Joe. It was there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So was half their team. (trailing off) Shit, another Christmas at home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next year, man. Next year we sell  out. Next year we dominate.

dialogues.speaker: ON COACH WINTERS AGAIN
dialogues.text: still fielding questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You still need a deep threat or a  breakaway back to go with Joe Kane.  What are you gonna do to address  this need?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little edgy) Stop wastin' my time talkin' to you  guys for a start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Winters gets up to go, we hear:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not gonna lead you into the fog  here, Sam...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHANCELLOR GRANT WILSON, 60, grey-haired eminence, sits b his desk. Seated across from him are Coach Winters and GA HOWARD, 50, the Athletic Director.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm concerned about our Program.  It's always been a source of pride  to our students and alumni, but two  straight so-so seasons are having a  damaging effect on our fund-raising,  both public and private.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (half-joking) Then stop raising the entrance  requirements on me. We never could  have gotten Alvin Mack in here under  the new guidelines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Chancellor, my first responsibility  is to the academic interests of this  University.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilson points to a representation of a football field aff to the wall. A football rests on the 40 yard line, which marked 160 million. The end zone (60 yards away) is  $400,000,000.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At a time when we're committed to a  400 million dollar building program,  alumni donations are down 15% the  last two years. Because they've also  voiced their displeasure to their  legislators, we can expect a  corresponding drop in state funds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Athletic Fund is suffering too.  Season tickets sales are off,  merchandising's slow...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You layin' all this at my door?  There's been a recession on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but the heaviest drop has been  from the big donors, the 100,000  dollar club. These people are  recession proof. They sit in my box  every game, and they're much more  generous when we're ranked and going  to bowl games. Two of them, as you  know, are on the Board of Regents,  including the Chairman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you trying to say to me,  Grant? After 12 years, my job's in  jeopardy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not prepared to discuss your job  right now; I just want you to be  aware of the situation. The alumni  and the legislature are unhappy and  they vote with their checkbooks. I  don't pretend to be an expert on  football, Sam, and I'll deny that  this conversation ever took place,  but I do know we need to win next  year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coach Winters flanked by two assistant coaches, HUMES and CLAYTON, walks down a cavernous tunnel beneath the stands a waiting car. At the end of the tunnel, a scarecrow EFFI of Coach Winters hangs from an overhead pipe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ignoring the effigy) Tickets are in your coat. Itinerary  and player profiles are in your  briefcase. We got a 9:00am tomorrow  in Philly with this kid Darnell  Jefferson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coach Winters stops, looks up at the effigy. Humes and Cl fear an outburst, a display of rage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like I've lost weight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it. He strides on. Humes and Clayton race to catch up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This kid's the gamebreaker we've  been lookin' for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Boeing 737 roars into the night sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Had a 108 yard kickoff return against  Taft. Michigan's been down to see  him twice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winters, Humes, Clayton and Joe Kane sit across from DARN JEFFERSON and REVEREND WALLACE in a tattered parlor room. Other boys of various ages and color look in from the  adjoining door. Darnell is black, good-looking, street-hi the letters D.J. shaved in block letters into his fade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darnell, you have the potential to  start for us as a freshman. That 108  yard kickoff return you made against  Taft? One of the greatest runs I've  ever seen a high school player make.  Now, Michigan is set at tailback for  two years. You won't play till you're  a junior. With Joe here gettin' you  the ball, runnin' 28 Thunder right,  you'll be All-American with us as a  Sophomore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but I'm really more concerned  with Darnell's education. He came  here late. He's got some catching up  to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Believe me, education is the first  priority in our program. That's why  all the players are smarter than me.  After all, a football coach is smart  enough to understand the game, but  dumb enough to think it's important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This gets a little chuckle from the Reverend. It was inte to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a run-down tenant SHACK on the edge of a large cot field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two rooms. Dirt floor. Two-foot Christmas tree on an appl cart. Alvin Mack's MOTHER opens a Christmas present as Al and his TWO SISTERS look on. It's an ENGRAVED LIONSHEAD  DOORKNOCKER, the kind you'de find on the door of an afflu home. The inscription reads THE MACK'S. Alvin's mother th it's beautiful, but isn't sure what to do with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's real pretty, Alvin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I turn pro, I'll get you the  house to go with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winters' daughter LOUANNE, 20, is on the phone with her  father. Louanne is sexy, clothes too tight, but good-natu somewhat needy and loyal as a labrador. She holds a hopel out-of-style sweater her dad's given her for Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lying) It's real nice, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winters sits on the bed, eating Chinese take-out, the pho cradled in his neck, talking to Louanne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew you'de like it, Lou. Merry  Christmas. Put some fresh flowers on  your Mom's grave for me. I'll be  home in a couple days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Battered and old, in a declining Pennsylvania neighborhoo hard by a STEEL WORKS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe sits on the couch with his older brother, FRANK, watc the bowl game he would have been in, had E.S.U. won their last game. His FATHER, a grizzled man in his fifties, nod in and out in a tattered armchair. All three have been  drinking beer, their empties scattered around. Frank toss Joe an Iron City beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have another Vitamin I, Joey. Didn't  think we'de see you here this  Christmas, little brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You won't next year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting up) Yeh, well we won't rent your place  on the couch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Joe's father heads for the kitchen, he hangs his empty beer can, by the pull tab, on a branch of the Christmas t We see that the whole tree is covered with cans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darnell talks on a pay phone in the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're from E.S.U?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeh. I was just sittin' here by the  fire doin' my homework, and decided  to give you a call. See how you're  doin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see who Darnell is talking to: AUTUMN HALEY, beautiful black girl, stylish, long straight hair, definitely not  street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coach Winters has been telling me  about you. I'm looking forward to  seeing you when you come to visit.  I'll be your guide. You are coming  to visit aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We PULL BACK and REVEAL Autumn in an office with 15 other telephones, a coed on every one. ASST. COACH MYERS superv with a clipboard of names and numbers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe leads Darnell down to the end of the tunnel, where Au is waiting. He introduces them. She's even more attractiv than Darnell thought she'd be. She takes Darnell's hand and leads him out onto the field where he's greeted by the E.S.U. BAND playing the school  fight song. The CHEERLEADERS whip into action, legs kicki pom-poms whirling. The band parts and Darnell walks out into the 90,000 seat stadium, an awesome sight for any young man. Autumn point to the giant DIAMOND VISION SCOREBOARD. Darnell's name an picture appear. The stadium P.A. ANNOUNCER cuts in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now for the starting line-up for the  E.S.U. Timber Wolves. At tailback,  number 20, Darnell Jefferson!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got that right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darnell, in his excitement, does a little end-zone dance. Slaps hands with Joe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romantic, Ivy-League look, lit by soft-glo footlights. Da and Autumn walk, side by side, stopping outside Autumn's  dorm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for showin' me around, Autumn.  I don't meet too many females like  you. You got a lotta class. Real  efficacious. Maybe I'll check you  out in the fall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope so, Darnell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leans down to kiss her. She hesitates, not sure about  this, then comes forward, kisses him on the lips, starts let it deepen, then breaks it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he watches her go up the steps, we go to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Early February: It's National Decision Day and Darnell's  home is under seige. Reporters. Microphones. Television  cameras. Darnell steps out onto the porch wearing an ESU  jersey with #1 emblazoned on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you know where I'm going and  what we're indubitably going to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC and TITLES END.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hot, late summer day. Over the deserted Quad, we see th title: 6 MONTHS LATER. It fades and we MOVE TO REVEAL a city BUS pulling up at a curb adjacent to the Quad. Off steps Darnell, carrying on battered suitcase. Joe Kane and BUD LITE KAMINSKY, offens line tackle, are there to greet him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Darnell, Welcome to E.S.U.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking hands) Yeh, good to see you guys. What  happened to the band and the dancin'  honies?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Regular students don't come back for  two weeks yet. Not that they woulda  been here. Now that you've enrolled,  you're just another wormshit freshman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dorm devoted exclusively to football players. Luxurious lounges, study halls, saunas, recreation and media rooms. Spacious living quarters. A world unto itself. Joe and Bud usher Darnell into his room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's your room. If you need anything  call the hall manager.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darnell looks around, taking it all in. He tries to be co but this is easily the nicest room he's ever had.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See ya later. Freshman Placement  test tomorrow at nine. McKinnley  Hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe and Bud start down the hall. Darnell turns back into room, then starts to pace off it's dimensions, heel to to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: College hang-out, bar, catering to athletes and their  admirers. A black HARLEY DAVIDSON, driven by Joe Kane wit Darnell on the back, pulls up at the curb. They get off,  head inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe and Darnell pass a table of three girls, conspicuous  among them is Louanne Winters. Joe and Darnell give her a nod and proceed on to a table where three fellow players  wait: Bud Lite, BOBBY COLLINS, good-looking, silver-tongu ladies man and 2nd string quarterback, and STEVE LATTIMER heavily muscled, surf-punk defensive end. Between them is large pitcher of beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, oh, the Lead Dog is back. There  goes my cover of the media guide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Bobby, Lats, how ya doin? This  is Darnell Jefferson, freshman  tailback.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How ya' doin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was hopin' you'de have rolled your  bike or somethin'. Nothin' serious,  just enough to keep you out for the  season.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pouring himself some  beer) No such luck, Backup Man. But I'll  try to engineer a few blowouts. Get  you get some mop-up time. (studying Lattimer) Shit, Lats, you look buffed, man.  You put on some weight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 35 lbs. Spent the summer in the gym.  I'm tired of watchin' you guys play.  I intend to start this year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You get any bigger, you can play  offense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeh, but don't I have to get dumber  too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud takes a good-natured swipe at him. Lattimer deflects Joe notices Bobby looking over at Louanne. She gives Bobb surreptitious little wave to come over and sit with her. gives her the "just a minute" sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You still seein' Louanne?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeh. Now and then, when the tide  rises. Don't want her to think this  is some kind've exclusive deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coach finds out you're nailin' his  daughter, you'll be playin' dorm  ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll bail before that. Besides, this  is what he gets for not startin' me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby laughs and heads over to Louanne's table, as Joe po himself another beer. Alvin enters the bar, goes to Joe's table, plops a copy o Sports Illustrated down in front of Joe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, man, you seen this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the cover is a picture of Joe and ONE OTHER QUARTERBAC TIM WAYMEN. The coverline reads, HEISMAN HOPEFULS: THE YE OF THE QUARTERBACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ribbing Joe) You must be some very bad-ass  motherfucker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe stares at the cover. He's more stunned than elated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? You didn't know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew there was gonna be an article.  I didn't know it was gonna be on the  cover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, we do all the work. You get  all the pub. Too bad we're not allowed  to hit you in practice. Be fun to  kick the shit out of a Heisman Trophy  Candidate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess you'll have to wait till we  get to the pros.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Darnell) Beer boy, get me some.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you serious?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does it look like I'm serious?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe drains his beer, pours another. Lattimer starts to re form the article.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to this. "E.S.U. has a solid  nucleus returning, but the  Timberwolves, coming off two  disappointing seasons, will only go  as far as the strong right arm of  Heisman Candidate Joe Kane will take  them." That right, Joe? You gonna  lead us to the promised land?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna lead... but can you follow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muted chuckles, but set faces. The challenge accepted. Jo chugs his beer, pours another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd from the 911 (Bud, Alvin, Lattimer, Darnell, Bo and Louanne) follow Joe down the hill behind the bar towa a busy two-lane highway. Joe, a little drunker than the  others, starts HOWLING at the moon like a Timber Wolf. Th others join in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are we doin', Joe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slightly slurred) There's something I wanta try. Gotta  wake up our Mojo. Start settin' the  tone for the season.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is not a good time to be settin'  anything. You're in no shape...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly Joe makes a dash out onto the highway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe, c'mon Joe, don't be an asshole.  Joe! God-damnit, why's he always  doin' shit like this? Coach'll fuckin'  kill me. Alvin, go get him, will ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell no, you go get his ass. Crazy  motherfucker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe stands on the white line, cars and trucks whizzing by then lies down on his back, arms at his side.

dialogues.speaker: JOE'S POINT OF VIEW
dialogues.text: Cars and trucks blast toward us, roar on by, right on top us, honking, spraying grime, shaking the asphalt. Bud and the others on the side of the road are increasing worried now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck this shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pissed off, Bud sprints out to the white line. The draft- wake of a passing truck almost blows him over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, Joe, that's enough. Let's get  the hell outa here. What if somebody  drifts or crosses the line to pass?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter, Bud? Can't you  follow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud hesitates a second, scared, but stung by this dare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (torn) God-damnit, god-damnit. Shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud can't fight it. He lies down on the line, his head  touching Joe's feet. Joe begins to HOWL again. Bud joins Alvin and the others can't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Startin' to look like a loaf of Wonder  bread out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're makin' us look like pussies,  ya know. Standin' here suckin' our  thumbs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Alvin) Yeh, and there's nobody from the  Defense out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby and Lattimer look at each other a beat. Time to ant up. Both turn to Alvin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you lookin' at? You think  you're bad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alvin snorts in disgust and starts out onto the blacktop. Bobby and Lattimer smile, go to follow. Louanne grabs Bob holds him back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (vaguely sexual) Bobby, be careful, o.k? Please, be  careful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby smiles, grabs her ass, pulls her to him, gives her long, passionate kiss, then sprints out to the white line leaving her breathless. Alvin, Bobby and Lattimer lie down in front of Bud. Now  there's a line of five, a human highway median. Everybody scared shitless, howling their lungs out. Louanne and Darnell watch from the side of the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This guy do this kinda shit a lot?  They never mentioned this in  recruiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally, Joe laughing wildly, jumps up and they all scram back to safety. Out of breath, but pumped up, they exchan exhilarated high fives. Alvin just shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty freshman football players, including Darnell, are  scattered at tables around the room, writing furiously in test booklets, as a PROCTOR paces the room. Darnell start to write an answer, stops, stumped. Worried, he looks at clock, goes on to the next page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darnell and Joe walk across campus. Darnell carries a  gleaming, chromed TROPHY with a football player on top. H still thinking about the test.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know... I left a lot of 'em  blank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, you'll do all right.  Lotta people don't finish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not convinced) Yeh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doin' with the trophy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coach Winters asked me to bring it  to the meeting. I don't know what  for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly Darnell sees Autumn walking across the Quad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll see ya at the meeting. (handing him the trophy) Take this for me, will ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe starts to protest, but Darnell is already off, racing across the Quad, quickly catching up with Autumn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Autumn, hold up! What're you  doing here? I thought students didn't  come back for two weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rather coolly) I came back early to see a friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're looking fresh, Autumn. A  package of pulchritudiness. What  about getting together later tonight?  Maybe get a pizza? They got pizza in  this town don't they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about tomorrow night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think it's a real good idea  for us to see each other, Darnell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter? I'm not good enough  for you all of a sudden? Too young,  is that it? I'm not, ya know. They  held me back a year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's not that... I've got a  boyfriend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you have this boyfriend when you  showed me around?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reluctant to admit  it) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, it didn't seem to bother  you then. I'm willing to overlook it  now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was mad at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I caught him with another girl. A  white girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you're still with this nigger?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods, slightly embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I got to get going, Darnell.  I'm sorry. I didn't mean to lead you  on. I'm glad you came here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts walking away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. I can at least walk  with you, can't I? Nothin' wrong  with that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She speeds up. He speeds up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in a hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can keep up. I run the forty in  four-four.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's just about to say something when RAY GRIFFEN arrive Ray's the starting tailback, black, handsome, clean-cut,  well-spoken, middle class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Autumn --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is exactly what Autumn didn't want to happen. Ray an Darnell eye each other like a couple of roosters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Ray. This is...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cutting in, offering  his hand) Darnell Jefferson. (pointedly) Tailback.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking Darnell's  hand) Ray Griffen. (just as pointedly) Starting tailback.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. That's why they recruited  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Autumn can't believe he said this. She starts to interjec something to break the tension, but never gets the chance

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two guys they recruited before  you are handing out Gatorade now. (making the jerkoff  motion) Better start strengthening your wrist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll see. (departing, to Ray) Give my best to Miss Lilly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Autumn's mortification is complete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself) What the hell is that supposed to  mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Establish the new, modern KELLER CENTER, home of the E.S. Athletic Department.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The football meeting room. A quarter amphitheatre. The  Freshman, including Darnell, down in front. Nervous, talk very little, eyes playing over the pictures of former E.S greats arranged on the Wall of Honor. Behind them, the Upperclassmen, bantering, conversation  punctuated with laughter. A door opens. The Assistant Coaches file in. The room hus immediately. Coach Winters walks in. The Upperclassmen br into applause; the Freshmen quickly take their cue and jo in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good to see you again, gentlemen. (catching sight of  Darnell) Jefferson, either take off the earring  or put on a dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The upperclassmen hoot, as Darnell, embarrassed, takes of his earring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanna talk a little about what  we're trying to do here. There are  many highly respected people who  feel football is about preparation  for life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The players nod reverentially at this established axiom o the football cannon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These people are full of shit. You  see, football is not like life. (pause) It's better. More exciting, more  intense, more fun. In life, people  are always wondering how they measure  up; whether they're getting ahead or  fallin' behind. In football, you  know. Every week you get a chance to  show what you're made of, a chance  to demonstrate the physical and  personal qualities that all those  poor bastards who can't play this  game are left to agonize about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spreading smiles all around. It's good to be a football  player.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last year we didn't make enough of  those chances. Last year everyone  felt we let the school down. Fuck  the school. We let ourselves down. (pointing to the Wall  of Honor) We let down a great tradition, a 120- year-old Line of Champions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The smiles are gone. Lots of set faces now. Shame. anger, retribution.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any football program worth the name  is a special brotherhood, an elite  corps of warriors, a select group of  knights. That first time our starting  unit takes the field, the first time  we huddle up; that's our inner circle,  that's our Round Table. If I were an  upperclassman, I'd be real nervous  about my seat, cause we got some  very talented new-comers this year.  Guys who want a place at the Table. (producing Darnell's  trophy from behind  the podium) This is the trophy one of our  freshman, Darnell Jefferson, won as  a Pennsylvania State High School  First Team All-American. You know  what this says to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The freshmen are hanging on every word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a god-damn thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smashes the trophy on the podium, breaking it in half, shattering the base. Darnell and the other freshmen are a The upperclassmen stifle laughs, particularly Ray Griffen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the freshmen) Everybody here was a high school All- American. (to all the players) Whatever any of you have done before  is out the window. We're startin'  over. Ground zero. The Table is empty.  Are you ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The upperclassmen nod, steely, purposeful. We go to the  freshmen. They're not so sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Passing drills. Joe Kane takes a snap, fades to pass, thr an out. The ball sails two feet over the receiver's head. Joe's angry with himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Winters) He's too pumped up. Tryin' to win  the damn Heisman on every throw. I'm  not sure he's ready for all this  hype.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little late to be worryin' about  that. If we don't follow up the Sports  Illustrated cover with something,  it'll look like we didn't believe in  our own player.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, Joe's a tough kid. He'll  be allright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scrimmage. Joe hands off to Darnell. He sweeps right, cut it up, blows past the end. In a spectacular display of br field running, Darnell breaks to the sideline, cuts back, eluding the corner back, and stiffarms the safety. Alvin, pursuing the play, finally tackles him from behind, strip the ball at the same time. There's a wild scramble for th fumble. Darnell is crushed under the pile, as the defense recovers it, ruining an otherwise brilliant run. The players unpile to reveal Darnell, writhing on the gro the wind knocked out of him. Ray Griffen runs by to take place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, nice writhing, Jefferson. You  got all the moves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting to the team) Allright, move it up. Let's go, 15  yards, run the next play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The scrimmage moves up 15 yards leaving Darnell behind.  Winters sprints over to Lattimer, grabs him by the face m

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut the necktie tackle horseshit.  You think you're in some kinda  highlight reel? He left you huggin'  air. Target his guts. Drive right  through his abdomen. I wanta see  snot bubbles in his nose. I wanta  see shit in his underwear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lattimer nods chastised. Winters moves over to check on  Darnell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You injured, Jefferson, or just hurt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gasping) What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're hurt, you can still play.  If you're injured you can't. Are you  hurt or are you injured?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'm just hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O.k., then get up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winters extends a hand. Darnell grabs it, struggles shaki to his feet

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice run. Think what it coulda done  for us if we still had the ball. (handing him the ball) This is a football. I want you to  carry it with you wherever you go.  Never let it out of your sight. (to the rest of the  team) Any of you see him on campus, take a  swipe at the ball. Try to knock it  out of his hands. Recover it. (to Darnell again) If anybody, but you, returns this  ball to me, you'll wish you'de never  been born.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winters wheels off leaving a wobbly Darnell alone with hi football.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't gonna get it, goddamnit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winters, mad as hell, is berating his assistant coaches w are sitting, cowed in his office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see tackling, but I don't see  hitting. I see effort, but I don't  see ferocity. What do you think,  they're gonna motivate themselves?  Football's just a game to most of  these kids. This is our program, our  livelihood. It's our job to make  them care as much about it as we do.  Make them hate me if you have to.  It'll bring them together, give them  a focus. So get off your butts and  put the fear of God in these guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dead tired players toweling off, dressing. The trainer's  room is crowded with aching, cramped-up, contused players Across the way, Lattimer lifts weights, alone in the weig room. Clayton and Humes consider this from outside Winter office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, Lattimer's an animal all of a  sudden. Benchin' 450. He's gotta be  on somethin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, steroids? Why do you always  think my guys are juicin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know... he's on the punt  team for three years, then gains 35  pounds of rip in one summer and an  attitude to go with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winters, who's heard all this, comes by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not doctors, gentlemen. The  NCAA has testing programs for this.  Let's let them worry about it. (to Clayton) Besides, it's not that hard to put  on 35 pounds in a summer, if you  really hit the gym.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winters walks on into his office. Clayton nods, realizing this subject is now closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darnell walks in, wrung out from the day's practice, stum to the bed where he sees something that stops him - lying there is his PENNSYLVANIA STATE ALL AMERICAN TROPHY. Coac Winters actually smashed a replica. A smile appears on  Darnell's tired face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For football players only. Bud Lite moves through the  cafeteria line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you got tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Choice of three entrees. Shrimp,  lasagna, T-bone steak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tough choice. I'll take all three.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a surprise.

dialogues.speaker: DARNELL
dialogues.text: at another table with Alvin and several other black playe Lattimer is the only white.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When do they give ya the scores on  that Placement Test?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who cares? I flunked it three times,  before I got in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long as you're in the program, they'll  get you through. Maybe not with a  degree, but they'll keep you eligible.  Just don't do nothin' embarrassing  they can't cover you for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, they even give Alvin copies of  his tests in advance. He sells 'em  for a hundred bucks a pop to people  in his class. 'Course he's gotta  have somebody read 'em to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you, doughboy. I can read. See  that shoe? (points to his shoes) That says Nike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I still don't wanna flunk that test.  I wanta get a degree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think, nigger? You're  gonna be on the Supreme Court? All  you need to know is how to sign an  N.F.L. contract.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darnell's stung by this. He'd like to think of himself as capable of more. Suddenly, Coach Winters appears at the door, a surprise  visitor to the training table. All the players wearing  baseball caps, quickly doff them. Winters is angry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter with you guys?  You're supposed to be a team. Winning  depends on thinking and acting and  going to war together. But you don't  even eat like a team. You eat like  two teams. A white one and a black  one. What do I have to do? Make out  a seating chart? Now get up. Move  around. Mix it up. Now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The players all look at each other, then reluctantly get and change tables. Darnell sits next to Joe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mock introduction) Hi there. Darnell Jefferson. I'm a  young black man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, glad to meet ya. Joe Kane,  Caucasian. So what doya think a that  new Garth Brooks album?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love that motherfucker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coach Winters surveys the scene, sees that all the tables are integrated now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's more like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and walks on out. Immediately, the players begin drift back to their old tables.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe, Bud Lite and Bobby Collins, all suffering from vario aches and pains are getting Naperson and analgesic balm o of the non-prescription drug cabinet. Joe pops a Nap and  looks across to the weight room where a stunning co-ed CA SCHAEFFER works a knee lift. Camille's the perfect marria of Southern patrician beauty and athletic confirmation. J leaves the others, heads over, pokes his head in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How ya' doin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little late to be workin' out, isn't  it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a little edge) Only time I could get in here when  the football team wasn't usin' it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to get a rise  out of her) Well, if it wasn't for the football  team, might not be a weight room to  use. You tryin' to firm up a little,  or what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unfazed) Don't need to firm up. I'm  strengthening my knee. Had  arthroscopic surgery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Had my knee scoped once too. When  you're finished here, maybe we could  get a yogurt, compare scars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, I don't date football players.  They're all full of themselves. I  saw you on the cover of Sports  Illustrated, so you're probably worse  than most.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's real open minded of you. So  you won't consider doin' anything  with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well at least tell me what happened  to your knee. What'd you do? Fall  outa your convertible?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camille stops her knee lift, turns to Joe. We think she's going to fire on him. Wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, there's maybe one thing  I'd do with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tennis. I'll play tennis with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camille starts to walk away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tennis. You mean now? It's raining.

dialogues.speaker: CAMILLE
dialogues.text: smashing a two-fisted forehand right at us, grunting with the exertion. Joe scrambles to get it back, but Camille's world-class player. She attacks with a vengeance, blastin every shot ala Jimmy Connors, as Bud Lite and Bobby Colli watch, amazed. We begin a SERIES OF CUTS detailing Camille's relentless  dismantling of Joe: Camille drilling a backhand down the  line, Joe barely getting it back to the net. Camille hitt a powerhouse service ace, Joe lunging and whiffing the re Camille crushing another forehand. Joe crushes it back, s it over the fence and into the parking lot. Camille servi again at match point. Joe pops up a weak return. Camille  puts it away with a powerhouse overhead, the ball almost  knocking Joe down. He flings his racket against the fence Camille comes to the net to shake hands, but Joe hangs ba

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for the game, Heisman. You  took it really well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And she walks away along to the net. Joe goes after her,  pissed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this Heisman crap?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camille's taken aback, not realizing she'd struck a nerve

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't say anything about being a  Heisman candidate. I don't go around  strokin' myself about it. So what's  this shit you're givin' me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... I'm sorry... I just figured you  were probably kissin' yourself in  the mirror every morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You figured wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now Joe walks away and Camille goes after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what do you want, an apology? I  just gave you one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want a rematch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A rematch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some other sport. I took my beating.  You owe me one. Either that or we go  out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camille considers, tries to figure out what she'd dislike least, knowing it'd be cheap to choose neither.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll think about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camille walks off, disappearing through the gate. Joe wal off in the other direction. Bud Lite and Bobby follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Real good date, Joe. Remind me to  take her out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Opening day of school. We take CUTS of students arriving, football players checking out the new girls from atop the wall of the athletic dorm, Louanne and Autumn greeting  returning sisters at the sorority, students registering f classes etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darnell sits across from WILLIAM SMITH, Academic Advisor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darnell, I've reviewed your placement  test and I'm afraid you failed to  meet our entrance requirements in  two areas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does that mean? I can't play  football?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. It means you're going to have to  take some remedial classes, what we  call "zero level" courses.  Specifically Math 0 and English 0.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darnell is clearly deflated by this painful indication of his academic standing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You won't get college credit for  them, but they will help you prepare  to take the Placement Test again at  the end of the quarter. If you pass  at that time you'll be able to  officially enter the university and  take college level courses. You'll  still be able to take an American  History survey course, but it won't  count on your record until you pass  the Placement Test. But first things  first. To start, I'm approving a  tutor for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tutor? I don't need no tutor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any tutor. And yes you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A meeting of the football brain trust; Coach Winters, Ath Director, GALEN HOWARD, a publicist, SHARON BRAVER, and t Sports Information Director (S.I.D.) LARRY NICHOLS. Also  present is Joe Kane, somewhat discomfited at being the ce of all this attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think both Joe and the university  are best served by a straightforward  Heisman campaign. Nothing too  gimmicky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've compiled a mailing list of  around 1300 opinion makers;  newspapers, football writers, and  sports anchors. First we send them a  packet on Joe and his achievements.  Bio, stats, plus human interest stuff;  commitment to academics, charity  work, etc. Then we update it each  week with a postcard. Heisman voters  hate opening envelopes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe is increasingly uneasy with all this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't really done any charity  work...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gonna start. We've got some  things lined up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unfortunately, because we weren't in  the top 20 last year, we only have  one network T.V. game to give Joe  national exposure. Although it's a  good one; Michigan. But we'll also  be taping all our other games and  buying satellite time. That way we  can produce our own highlight package  and interview pieces and send them  out to T.V. stations all over the  country for their sportscasts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any questions, Joe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If Joe was uneasy before, he's overwhelmed now. He tries to show it. After all, who could turn down a Heisman camp Still it's a megaton of pressure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, no... I just... you really think  I got a shot to win this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, yes. Plus it's a good thing  for the program. Publicizes the  school, gives a boost to recruiting,  and it's a great thing for you. Jumps  up your draft position, the size of  your first contract, everything.  It's a hell of an opportunity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All you gotta do is back it up on  the field, and we have no doubts  about that, cause we know "Kane is  Able."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nichols holds up a black CAMPAIGN BUTTON with the phrase  "Kane is Able" enblazoned on it in gold letters. This get rise out of everyone except Joe, who's still not sure abo all this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe lies on his bed, staring up at the ceiling, unable to get to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone rings. Camille, who's been asleep, rolls over a answers it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Joe Kane. What did you decide?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still drowsy) What? (looking at the clock) It's 3:00 in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanta know what you decided.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know... I couldn't think of  any other sports I could beat you  at.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I'll pick you up tonight at  6:00.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Autumn sits at a tutorial table, looking at her notes. Sh becomes aware of someone approaching. She looks up to see Darnell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Autumn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Darnell. What are you doin here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My advisor says I need a tutor. Ya  know, just to get me over a couple  rough spots. (showing her a paper) I saw your name on this list. I  figured if you couldn't keep my  attention, nobody could.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Darnell, but I've already  been assigned. You're gonna have to  find somebody else. I'm tutoring  Scott Sherman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not anymore. I asked Coach Winters  to switch us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coach Winters wouldn't do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeh he would. I'm a bigger prospect  than Sherman. (pointing across the  way) He's a lineman on the scout team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Autumn looks back to where Darnell is pointing. Sure enou SCOTT SHERMAN is hard at work with another Tutor. Autumn  can't believe it. She tries to compose herself. Darnell sits down across the table from her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon Autumn, you could teach me  some real erudition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to whisper,  pissed) Will you stop using those big words.  It sounds ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (serious about this) What doya mean? I'm improvin' myself.  I learn a new word out of the  dictionary every day. Mendacious,  pejorative, antithetical,  commensurate...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you don't ever use them right.  Pretending to be smart is not the  same as being educated. Or erudite.  It's just a con. And it makes you  sound stupid, no matter how big a  prospect you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darnell is genuinely hurt by this dose of reality. His  customary bravado melts away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O.K... even more reason for you to  be my tutor. You already taught me  something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Autumn, disarmed by his sudden humility, has no real rebu She would have had to tutor him anyway, but now she's hav trouble being angry about it.

dialogues.speaker: ALVIN MACK
dialogues.text: At another table, looking distracted and bored as his TUT reads his history assignment to him. Alvin takes out a wa and puts the headphones on. WE HEAR A HORN BEEP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camille comes out the front door, summoned by the horn. S stops at the sight of something. We REVERSE TO REVEAL Joe his Harley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We goin' on that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeh. I thought we might take a ride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I promised my dad I'd never get on  one of those.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you, one of these trust- fund princesses? It's fine for me to  play a game I don't know, but I ask  you to try somethin' different and  you hide behind your daddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds out a motorcycle helmet toward her, daring her. burns, but her competitiveness makes it impossible for he to decline this challenge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snatching the helmet) All right. But we go slow. No cowboy  stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe smiles and kicks the starter. Camille climbs on and t roar off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just outside town. Joe and Camille come down the highway moderate speed. Camille's hanging on for dear life, but w can tell she's enjoying it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This speed, o.k.?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeh, fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe immediately accelerates, throwing Camille's head back Her SHRIEK is lost in the whine of the engine, as they sp away from camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slow down, damnit. Joe... Joe!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They approach a high-banked turn, beyond which appears to a long, sheer dropoff. Joe looks back at Camille, smiles  devilishly, not looking where he's going. Camille sees th heading straight for the edge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (freaked) Joe, look out!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too late. Joe brakes, fishtails, but goes over the top of the bank, off the edge, flying out into oblivion, Camille screaming.

dialogues.speaker: HARLEY
dialogues.text: As it plops down onto a wide LEDGE not visible from the r three feet below the top of the bank. Joe lands it, skids a professional stop, breaks into raucous laughter. Camill jumps off the bike, scared stiff and livid with anger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could you do that, you stupid  punk? It isn't funny, god-dammit,  you coulda killed us! You're crazy,  you know that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it easy. I've done that a hundred  times. No big deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeh? Then why are you shaking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) I don't know... I guess cause I've  never done it with someone else on  the bike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just wanted to scare me. Are you  happy now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeh, pretty much. And the scream was  even better than I thought it'd be.  Every dog within hearing distance  wants to mate with you now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camille's ready to throttle him, then something catches h ear. Sure enough, there are SEVERAL DOGS BARKING in the  distance. Joe smiles at her. She looks away, still angry, but amused in spite of herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Working class, sawdust floor, George Thoroughgood's "Who You Love" on the jukebox. Camille and Joe are sitting in booth. Joe putting away the beers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You come here a lot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now and then. Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not exactly a campus favorite.  This is almost like hidin' out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like places where nobody knows me.  This too low-rent for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, my dad owned a place like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your dad? You mean he owned a chain  of these?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not everybody with a Southern accent  has their own plantation. My dad  could never afford to send me here.  I learned to play tennis on public  courts. Mighta been able to play pro  someday, if I hadn't hurt my knee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're just a scholarship jock  like me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeh. You disappointed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I've just never been out with a  jock before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that what we're doin' here? Goin'  out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. What doya think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe gets up, takes Camille's hand and pulls her to her fe They dance to a slow song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you're crazy for jeopardizing  your scholarship and a pro future by  jumping motorcycles off of highways.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just tryin' to keep my edge, Camille.  The other guys look to me cause they  think I'll do anything. I lose that,  I'm just another guy, and we all get  our ass kicked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, Joe. You scare me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe roars in on his motorcycle. Parks. Starts inside. Fin himself face to face with a very unhappy Coach Winters.  Winters holds out his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The keys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe hesitates a second, then reluctantly hands over his  motorcycle keys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you, as long as you're in  this program, you don't take  unnecessary risks off the field. A  man in contention for the Heisman  Trophy should be able to remember  that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe nods, contrite. Winters just walks on off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Autumn is tutoring Darnell, checking her lesson notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O.K., using the things we worked on  yesterday, I want you to write a two  or three page essay on some aspect  of your life. Something other than  football.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your father, maybe. You could write  about your dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't know that much about him. He  was off in Detroit workin' in a car  plant when I was born. Got laid off,  tried to rob a jewelry store to get  us some money. He died in prison.  Some kinda heart problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Autumn wasn't ready for this level of hardship. She tries press on gamely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about your mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was always workin'. Usually two  jobs. Comin' home one night she  stopped to get us some root beer.  Got caught in a gang crossfire. Shot  three times... died on the way to  the hospital. You want me to write  about that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blown away) No...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good, 'cause none of it's true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Autumn jumps up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (raising her voice) Jesus Christ, Darnell what a terrible  thing to do to somebody. That's not  funny. That's sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Autumn realizes she's in the library and sits back down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Had ya goin', didn't I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (soft library voice) No you didn't. You just... How could  you make up somethin' like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (contrite now) Sounded more interesting than the  truth. My mom took a vacation to  Chicago when I was 12. Never came  back. Don't know who my dad was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Autumn's anger melts away in the face of this painful tru

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who took care of you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I started hangin' with the J.B.M.,  gang-bangin'... Did some time in the  Hall. Reverand Wallace saw me playin'  football on a juvenile probation  team. Took me in, got me into high  school. Only reason they accepted me  was 'cause I could play football.  Sorta like here. Football saved my  life. I'd be nowhere without football.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Autumn just nods, still trying to take this all in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, then... maybe you could write  about football this once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeh, o.k... thanks. (pause) I've seen a lotta shitty things in  my life, Autumn. That's why I know  when I see somethin' good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Autumn knows this is no line. He means it. She's seeing h with new eyes. Moved by his pain, engaged by his sincerit and more than a little taken by his regard for her.

dialogues.speaker: ON ALVIN
dialogues.text: across the room with his tutor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's review the chapter I read you  yesterday. Which two city states  fought in the Punic Wars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno. Detroit and Buffalo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, Alvin. You're gonna be tested  on this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A video projector projects various football formations on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Alvin, this is Mississippi  State's offensive set. 2nd and 2 on  our 24. What defense are you in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eagle. Zipper. Hero. Unless the set  back shifts into the I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. (slide changes) How about here? 3rd and 7.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okie. Thunder. Lion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your assignment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kill the Quarterback. (slide changes) Hit the tight end so hard his  girlfriend dies. (slide changes) Kill everybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe watches Bud Lite, Darnell, Alvin and Lattimer file in and unveil a life-size CARDBOARD STAND-UP of Joe's Sports Illustrated cover pose. They whoop it up, as Joe tries to muster some enthusiasm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Autumn's pointing out a figure on a graph in Darnell's ma book. As she explains, Darnell leans close to kiss her. A quickly leans away, glances around to see if anyone saw  Darnell's attempt. Darnell laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group of football players sits in the back of the class As the HISTORY PROFESSOR lectures at the board, Darnell  furiously takes notes. Scott Sherman, seizing the opportu leans forward from the desk behind him and pokes the foot out of Darnell's left hand. Darnell, Scott and two other  FRESHMAN FOOTBALL PLAYERS spring out of their seats,  scrambling after the loose ball. The prof and the other  students watch appalled as Darnell and the others dive un chairs and overturn desks in pursuit of the elusive ball. Finally, Darnell, winded and disheveled, comes up with it He and the others quickly return to their seats. The prof looks at Darnell aghast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry... I lost my football.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe and Camille are locked up in a furious game of raquet Joe makes a wicked kill shot on the last point, and pumps fist in triumph. Camille, pissed at losing, throws her ra and stomps around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darnell and Autumn are having a daytime tutoring session a secluded patch of lawn. Darnell holds his football. As begins to read aloud from East of Eden, Autumn pokes the  ball out of his hand. They both scramble for it, Darnell  winding up slightly on top of her. They eye each other a  beat. Darnell bends down to kiss her. She lets herself ki him for a second, then gets up and starts to collect her  books.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several of the players are gathered around a bulletin boa in the hall. The starting lineup for the first game has b posted. Darnell traces his finger from the designation  TAILBACK over to the name RAY GRIFFEN. He drops his eyes, obviously disappointed. Lattimer, meanwhile, is checking the defensive board. He  finds his name posted as a starting defensive end. Punchi the air, he dashes out of the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes!! Starting defense. Place at the  table. Whooo!! Yes!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lattimer, in his euphoria, races out into the lot, and be head-butting car windows. He breaks out three in a row, a yells in triumph, his forehead dripping blood. Winters, walking with the TEAM TRAINER, has seen this fro across the street. He knows there's something dark at wor here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: N.C.A.A. is gonna test half the team  before the game Saturday. Make sure  Lattimer knows about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chairs are arranged in several circles, ten players t circle, like a bunch of formalized huddles. Coach Winters addresses the assembly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the veteran players know, we have  Pride Night every year before our  opening game. It's a chance to get  to know each other better, share  some thoughts, and bring us closer  together as a team. So to start off,  I'd like each player to tell the  others in his group what he likes  best about football and then what  he's most proud of off the field.  I've asked some of the seniors to  lead it off. Gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know... It's the battle. The  goin' to war with the other guys.  Hangin' together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The team walks through several plays. They wear coats and ties, but no socks. Their ankles are taped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bein' different from everybody else.  Havin' our own dorm, stayin' in hotels  the night before games. Settin'  ourselves apart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before the game. An NCAA OFFICIAL gives Lattimer a little test tube to urinate in for his drug test. Lattimer goes  into one of the restroom stalls, reaches around to the ba of the tank, where a VIAL OF CLEAN URINE is taped. He pou it in the test vial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Havin' a chance to be somebody. To  do somethin' that people look up to  you for. Your strength and your  courage. Not everybody can play  football. We're the lucky ones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The thing I'm most proud of myself  for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darnell listening to a Walkman, is going through a pregam ritual by his locker; pivoting from leg to leg, switching the ball from arm to arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just that I'm here. That I'm not  dead or in jail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The great thing about football is  you can lose yourself in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe sits off in a corner by himself, his head back agains the wall, staring out into space, the only movement the  rhythmic tapping of his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no time to think, to worry,  to have doubts. Everything else fades  away. You just move and react.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The best thing is when you dominate.  That feeling when you hit a guy real  good, really stick him, and you hear  that little moan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alvin, his ass-kicking game face on, walks over to where  Lattimer is finishing decorating his face with Indian war paint. They chuck each other's pads, then Lattimer opens mouth. Alvin spits into it. Then Lattimer spits into Alvi Darnell can't believe this shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know it's killin' him, but you  feel great. It's just him and you,  and he's the one that's hurtin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We move in on the burning ferocity of Alvin's eyes and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Players are bunched together in the tunnel, slapping  pads, yelling encouragement. Winters waves them forward.  They start to run down the tunnel. PLAYERS P.O.V. CAMERA runs with the players as the light at the end of t tunnel becomes larger and brighter. Crowd NOISE becomes l until finally the camera emerges into the stadium and the light and 95,000 VOICES ROAR. AND ROAR! AND ROAR! This is Big Time College Football.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: E.S.U. announcer BRAD HARVEY and colorman, HARMON SLOAN a holding forth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome everybody to the Wolf Den  where the E.S.U. Timberwolves, led  by Heisman candidate Joe Kane, open  their season against the tough  Mississippi State Bulldogs under  head coach Jackie Sherrill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd stands, waving banners, as the E.S.U. kicker co forward and kicks the ball high into the fall sky. The  MISSISSIPPI STATE RETURN MAN fields the ball at the four  yard line and returns it to the 22 where he's buried. The defense trots out and huddles up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, let's get evil. 60 minutes,  balls out. Let's open a can of kick- ass. Kill 'em all. Let the paramedics  sort 'em out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mississippi State offense breaks it's huddle, comes t the line of scrimmage. Alvin, prowling behind the line, l eyes with the tailback, No.23.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, 23, don't think I don't recognize  you, you little fuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tailback looks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, pay attention when I'm talkin'  to you, nigger. You're the guy that  shot my mother aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were tryin' to steal her fuckin'  car weren't you, cocksucker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up. I never heard of your mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the sidelines, Darnell is watching this exchange.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Joe) What's Alvin saying to that guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just gettin' himself pumped up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wasn't pumped up already?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to tailback) Thought I'd never find you didn't  ya? But I got you now nigger, and  I'm gonna kill you motherfucker. I'm  gonna bust your guts open and watch  you die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ball is snapped. The quarterback pitches to the tailb as Alvin charges into the hole, screaming at the top of h lungs. The tailback, eyes wide with fear, cuts back, away from Alvin, where he's promptly crunched by Lattimer. The ball flies loose, there's a scramble, Alvin comes up with it. E.S.U. ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bench and stands erupt as Lattimer and Alvin but head and trot off the field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Atta baby, Alvin, heads up. Big pop,  Steve, way to stick 'em. (turning to Joe) O.K. Joe, let's go up top. Take it  to 'em right away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe leads the offense on. A disappointed Darnell stands o the sidelines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in huddle) O.K. let's put the women and children  to bed, and go lookin' for dinner.  Don't let em up. 51 Strike, Orange  left. On 4.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe begins to howl like a wolf. The others join in. A pac of Timberwolves. They break the huddle, come to the line scrimmage. Bud Lite begins to sing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bali Hi, will call you, anytime, any  day. Here am I, your special island...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud lines up opposite a big, black DEFENSIVE TACKLE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up, snowflake. You think you're  in the school play?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Bali Hi, the endzone is calling.  And the highway runs right over your  ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullshit, you're gonna be my bitch,  baby. You gonna be my punk bitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing again) So long, farewell, auf Wiedersehen,  good night, I hate to go and leave  this pretty sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe hits the 4 count, and the ball is snapped. Bud Lite a the Big Tackle fire out. Bud drives a forearm into the st of the Black Tackle, doubling him over. The Black Tackle  comes back, slamming a forearm up under Bud's chin, snapp his neck back. Joe, meanwhile, fades to pass, pump fakes, steps up. Bud  Lite, chicken fighting the Black Tackle, sticks his finge in the Tackle's eyes, then cut-blocks him to the ground. Tackle falls on Bud, and smashes a fist into his ribs. Bu rolls him over. Joe spots his flanker back, MAURICE WARD, on a flag patte Lofts a perfect spiral to him in the corner of the endzon Touchdown. The crowd goes wild, as Bud Lite pushes off the Black Tac throat getting up from the pile. Joe pumps a fist in the  air, hugs Ward, as the team celebrates. MUSIC BEGINS.

dialogues.speaker: SCOREBOARD
dialogues.text: It reads E.S.U. 28, Mississippi State 20. 4th Quarter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jefferson! In for Griffen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darnell jazzed at his first chance to see action, buttons his chinstrap, races onto the field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 2:05 left. Kane hands to Jefferson...

dialogues.speaker: DARNELL
dialogues.text: He takes a handoff, runs a trap up the middle, is hit by  THREE TACKLERS, clawing at the ball. They bring him down, but Darnell doesn't fumble. He gets up, still clutching t ball, and starts back to the huddle with it. The REFEREE  hustles after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, son, but we're gonna need  that football for another couple  minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darnell, suddenly realizing, gives it up. Even Winters ha to laugh. We go to:

dialogues.speaker: LATTIMER
dialogues.text: Lattimer, sacking the quarterback, tackling him high, rip his helmet off. Lattimer runs off the field, holding it u like a trophy. The gun sounds, the game is over.

dialogues.speaker: COACH WINTERS
dialogues.text: Accepting congratulations from his staff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess we'll be on the payroll for  another week.

dialogues.speaker: BUD LITE AND THE BLACK TACKLE
dialogues.text: walking off the field together, both their jerseys blood- stained.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good game, man. Really enjoyed it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeh, you're a strong motherfucker.  Shitty singer though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A reception of some sort for the players is in progress.  Darnell, looking a little lost, fills his cup from a punc bowl. A FAT CAT ALUMNUS approaches him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good to see ya in there, Darnell.  Way to hold on to that pigskin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he walks by, he slips an ENVELOPE into Darnell's coat  pocket. Darnell opens it to find a 50 dollar bill. Surpri he goes over to Alvin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, some guy just gave me a 50 dollar  bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, you'll get 5 or 6 hundred  once you're startin', depending on  how you play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we're not supposed to get any  are we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, man, you can't live on $500 a  month scholarship money. And the NC  double assholes won't let us have  jobs, so you take your money where  you can get it. (taking Darnell's  envelope) I'll keep it for you, till you see  the light. Shit, they oughta be payin'  us anyway. Athletic Department gets  3 million just for goin' to a bowl  game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe sits alone on his bed watching T.V. He's being interv in the locker room, a bouquet of microphones in his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This performance today -- two  touchdown passes, another you ran  in. Where do you think this puts you  in the Heisman race?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe hates this question. We go to the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uncomfortable) I really have no idea. That's up to  you guys.

dialogues.speaker: SCREEN
dialogues.text: The image changes to ESPN anchor CHRIS BERMAN in the stud

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now let's turn to our Heisman watch. (does the pose while  remaining seated) We begin with Sports Illustrated  cover boy Joe Kane of E.S.U. who led  his team to an impressive victory  this afternoon. Well, if Joe continues  to raise Kane, he may well be Able  to dust off a large space on his  trophy shelf. Although the real test  will come in four weeks against  Michigan and their Heisman hopeful,  Tim Waymen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe walks across campus, headed for Camille's dorm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michigan also won big today. Timothy,  "He Could Go All The Way Men", will  be looking to do so against the  Timberwolves. And of course the able  Kane will be looking to also. I can't  wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe comes down the hall, knocks on Camille's door. No ans Knocks again. Nothing. Disappointed, he turns and walks a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The post-game victory party is in full swing. All the pla their girls and various groupies, dancing, drinking,  celebrating. Bud Lite and Joe stand drinking beer, watchi the action.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, I never seem to make  out at things like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby, who's overheard this, walks by with Louanne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't make out anywhere. Or did  you finally break the snatch barrier  this summer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you, Bobby. (realizing Louanne's  there) Excuse me, Louanne.

dialogues.speaker: DARNELL
dialogues.text: sitting across the room with Alvin but his attention is o Autumn and Ray out on the dance floor. Alvin notices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it, nigger. No chance for you  there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Griffin's goin' to medical school.  She likes that light-skinned  respectable shit. You're just her  ghetto toy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
